description: Borrowed from Hindi ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ü (khƒÅ·π≠), from Sauraseni Prakrit ëÄîëÄùëÅÜëÄùëÄ∏ (kha·π≠·π≠ƒÅ), from Sanskrit ‡§ñ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ (kha·π≠vƒÅ, ‚Äúbedstead‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (Canada, US) A simple bed, especially one for portable or temporary purposes.
(UK, Australia, New Zealand) A bed for infants or small children, with high, often slatted, often moveable sides.
(nautical, historical) A wooden bed frame, slung by its corners from a beam, in which officers slept before the introduction of bunks.

description: From Middle English cot, cote, from Old English cot and cote (‚Äúcot, cottage‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *kutƒÖ, *kut«≠ (compare Old Norse kot, Middle High German k≈´z (‚Äúexecution pit‚Äù)), from Scythian (compare Avestan ê¨êê¨Äê¨ôê¨Ä‚Äé (kata, ‚Äúchamber‚Äù)). Cognate to Dutch kot (‚Äústudent room; small homestead‚Äù). Doublet of cote; more distantly related to cottage.

examples: One evening  [‚Ä¶]  we were on a sudden, greatly astonished, by hearing a violent knocking on the outward Door of our rustic Cot.

entries.meaning: A pen, coop, or similar shelter for small domestic animals, such as sheep or pigeons.

description: From Irish cot, coit (‚Äúsmall boat‚Äù), from Proto-Celtic *quontio, from Proto-Indo-European *p√≥ntoh‚ÇÅs (‚Äúpath, road‚Äù), related to Gaulish and Latin ponto. Compare the first element of catboat, which could be a borrowing.

From dialectal cot, cote, partly from Middle English cot (‚Äúmatted wool‚Äù), from Old English *cot, *cotta, from Proto-Germanic *kutt√¥ (‚Äúwoolen fabric, wool covering‚Äù); and partly from Middle English cot, cote (‚Äútunic, coat‚Äù), from Old French cote, from the same Germanic source (see English coat). Possibly influenced by English cotton.

entries.meaning: A cover or sheath; a fingerstall.
examples: a roller cot (the clothing of a drawing roller in a spinning frame)
a cot for a sore finger

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A man who does household work normally associated with women.
examples: You know, that being an old bachelor, and somewhat of an epicure, he is at home, what the vulgar call a cot; and has laid down his spontoon for the tasting spoon, converted his sword into a carving knife, and his sash into a jelly bag.
